fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L be a frame and j : L \to L a nucleus on it. The set of fixed points of j forms a maxset.
In impredicative locale theory, the notion of a maxset is defined as:

Let L be a frame. A subset M \subseteq L is called a maxset if,
it is closed under arbitrary meets, and
it is an exponential ideal i.e. \forall x \in L. \ \forall m \in M. \ (x \Rightarrow m) \in M.
It is a standard fact of locale theory that there is a correspondence between the set of nuclei on, and the class of maxsets of, every frame.
Let L be a frame and j : L \to L a nucleus on it. The set of fixed points of j forms a maxset.

Let L be a frame. A subset M \subseteq L is called a maxset if,
it is closed under arbitrary meets, and
it is an exponential ideal i.e. \forall x \in L. \ \forall m \in M. \ (x \Rightarrow m) \in M.
For any frame L, there is a bijection between the set of nuclei on L and the class of maxsets of L.

Given a nucleus j : L \to L, we map it to its maxset of fixed points: \mathfrak {F} _j \vcentcolon \equiv \{ x \in L \mid j(x) = x \} , and given a maxset M \subseteq L, we map it to the nucleus defined by j_M(x) \vcentcolon \equiv \bigwedge \left \{ m \in M \mid x \le m \right \} . We need to show that these give a section-retraction pair.

Let j : L \to L be a nucleus. We need to show j = j_{ \mathfrak {F} _j}. For the ( \le ) direction, notice that for every x \in L, j(x) \le \bigwedge \{ y \in \mathfrak {F} _j \mid x \le y \} must be the case since j(x) is clearly a lower bound of \{ y \in \mathfrak {F} _j \mid x \le y \}.
Let M be a maxset. We need to show M = \mathfrak {F} _{j_M}.
